text: I have no problem how the new generation player act on the field.  I'm a genXer, and I remember the Boomer's and Great generation being critical on our baseball dress code (backwards hat in warm ups like Griffey Jr.,  low brim over eyebrows like Dave Stewart, Oakley Blades like Rickey, and even eliminating stir-ups).  I'm now the old guy that cant stand flat brims or crooked hats.  However, Garvey is not wrong in his assessment.  Sure Home Runs are an important part of the game.  Dave Kingman, Dale Murphy, Mark McGuire, and Jose Canseo are all examples of players in the 80's that were known for risk reward fence swinging.  However, taking a few strikes when you are down by two runs is baseball common sense.  Putting the ball in play is indeed better than a strikeout. Always allow your opponent to make the mental or physical error rather than you.  Now, if you have a hitter count go ahead and dig in and hack away.  Otherwise, Garvey is accurate when it comes to playoff baseball.  A perfect example is game 7 of the 2001 world series when the best closer in baseball history (Rivera) blew a save to the base to base Diamondbacks to lose the World series. Look it up.

My young sons are showing some interest in football, although they mostly enjoy hockey. text: I smoked as a teen, and then I got married had kids, so for 20 years I quit. Life changed and the work hard, play hard finally caught up to me. I have been on hydro's 7.5 for about 9 years. I adhere to what the  script  says. Now I get treated as a addict. MJ does more for me than pain killers. My body is addicted to pain killers, but mentally I am not. I would rather use something that has been around thousands of years as a remedy, than some one who cooked up chemicals that do work but are highly addictive and now the Gov if they had their way would like to make both harder to attain. If you are in pain 24hrs a day for so many years, you really  get to a point where you don't care. There have been times in my life where I had a episode that the pain was so bad that offered I would have shot heroin or morphine I didn't care, and I made a promise to myself I would never use a needle on myself. I have kept that promise for over 50 yrs, but like I said there has been times, pain can really screw with your mind. I would have a natural drug that won't kill you, and doesn't have bad side affects. And people I have quit things in my life, and MJ was the no big deal, compared to cigs which I have tried a number of times is hell. Quitting a anti depressants is no joy ride. MJ is only addictive if you think it is, but there is no huge side affects. I have been given drugs that said a side affect were what I was taking to get rid of. And my problem is I have a high tolerance. I have seen people take the lowest of hydros and they act drunk. All hyro's do for me is make my pain tolerable which is ok. To be pain free, means a much stronger drug, and the stronger you take, the harder to get off. So I stay at bearable and suffer, but it is much better than going up and down.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Adrian Gonzalez, a clubhouse leader, chooses not to join Dodgers for this World Series
context_meta.summary: There is no better World Series tradition than the introduction of each player in uniform. If you work for the home team, you get a nice round of applause, even if you are an obscure reliever, a quality assurance coach or a soft tissue specialist. The fan favorites draw the loudest and most sustained applause. Adrian Gonzalez would get a warm ovation, but he is not expected to join the Dodgers for the World Series. It's his choice. It's too bad. Gonzalez has played more games without a World Series appearance than all but two active players: Ichiro Suzuki and Brandon Phillips.
